repnme.cdata!:
Cote d'Ivoire - Postconflict
            Reconstruction and Recovery Grant Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Postconflict
            Reconstruction and Recovery Grant Project for Cote
            d'Ivoire were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory; risk to development outcome was moderate; bank
            performance was satisfactory; and borrower performance was
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            first, a country emerging from a prolonged and severe crisis
            can still achieve significant progress as long as its
            government demonstrates ownership and commitment to reform;
            second, rapid bank support to a country in a post conflict
            period can be effective in supporting the return to
            stability; third, the effectiveness of a Bank development
            policy  operation can be enhanced by its complementarities
            with other Bank financed operations and the efforts of other
            active donors in the reform areas; and fourth, when
            operations are prepared under difficult situations of
            institutional and/or political fragility, it may be
            important to limit the number and ambition of intermediate
            outcomes indicators.

repnme.cdata!:
Cote d'Ivoire - Post Conflict
            Reconstruction and Recovery Grant Project : summary of discussion

abstracts.cdata!:
The Executive Directors approved a
            single tranche grant to the Republic of Cote d'Ivoire
            in the amount of SDR 93.9 million (US$150 million
            equivalent) on the payment terms and conditions set out in
            the President's Memorandum. Directors expressed support
            for the objectives of the grant and welcomed its alignment
            with the government's new poverty reduction strategy.
            Speakers emphasized the need to support government recovery
            efforts and deepen reforms in public expenditure management.
            Directors also urged enhanced governance, transparency and
            accountability in the key sectors of cocoa, energy and
            finance and expressed hope for timely progress toward
            Completion Point for Heavily-Indebted Poor Country (HIPC)
            debt relief. Executive Directors endorsed the grant's
            emphasis on promoting reconciliation, youth employment, and
            economic recovery.

repnme.cdata!:
Cote d'Ivoire - Post-Conflict
            Reconstruction and Recovery Grant Program

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Post-Conflict
            Reconstruction and Recovery Grant (PCRRG) Program for Cote
            d'Ivoire is to provide a rapid response to a new
            government in dire financial straits while supporting
            essential reforms to improve governance, transparency and
            efficiency in public expenditure management and in the key
            sectors of cocoa, energy and finance. This program document
            states a program for the Republic of Cote d'Ivoire in
            the amount of SDR 93.9 million (US$ 150 million equivalent).
            The grant provides a bridge between past objectives and
            future operations, pursuing reforms initiated in previous
            grants while responding quickly to the emergency resulting
            from the recent crisis and the need to re launch economic
            growth. Cote d'Ivoire's political situation
            suffered a sharp reversal after the long-awaited
            Presidential elections of November 2010. Elections were held
            peacefully and in a manner generally considered to be free
            and fair. However, the Constitutional Court disqualified a
            large number of ballots and awarded President Laurent Gbagbo
            the victory, while the UN insisted that Alassane Ouattara
            had won. A political stalemate resulted and eventually led
            to a short-lived civil war; five months, many lives and much
            economic wealth were lost. An estimated 3,000 persons died,
            over 100,000 fled the country, and approximately one million
            were internally displaced. Three months of fiscal revenues
            were lost and the country accumulated new arrears with
            domestic and external creditors. The new government faces a
            daunting task of promoting reconciliation while providing
            justice and rebuilding the economy. The operation would
            provide urgently-needed financial support to the government
            in the context of an economy which virtually ground to a
            halt for two months. The PCRRG reflects the orientations for
            Bank engagement in states emerging from conflict as outlined
            in the 2011 World Development Report on Conflict, Security
            and Development and in the new Africa Strategy. First, it is
            rapid-response support aimed at breaking the cycle of
            repeated violence that has been observed in many
            post-conflict states. Second, while its objectives are
            modest, in recognition of the limited time available for the
            new government to define its priorities, the operation
            promotes incremental institutional change to improve
            governance and build confidence. Third, the areas supported
            by the operation reflect a high degree of selectivity on a
            small number of reforms that are feasible given the complex
            political situation.
